hints.content: First, consider the properties of a three-digit number. It must have a hundreds place, a tens place, and a units place. Remember that the number cannot start with zero.
Since you need to form even numbers, focus on the last digit of the number. What digits from the array can be used as the last digit to ensure the number is even?
Identify the even digits in the provided array. These digits will be crucial for forming valid three-digit even numbers.
Next, think about how to choose the first two digits. The first digit cannot be zero, so ensure you only consider valid options for the hundreds place.
When forming the three-digit number, remember that digits can only be used once per number. How will you keep track of which digits have been used?
Consider using a combination of loops and conditions to generate the three-digit numbers. You might want to iterate over the possible last digits first.
As you generate combinations, think about how you will ensure that the numbers are distinct. You might want to use a set to store the valid numbers.
Don't forget to handle edge cases, such as when the array contains duplicate digits. How will you ensure that duplicates don't lead to counting the same number multiple times?
After generating the numbers, remember to count them. What data structure will you use to store the valid three-digit even numbers before counting them?
Finally, ensure your solution adheres to the constraints. For instance, if the array has fewer than three digits or no even digits, how will you handle those cases?

questionNotes: Each digit can only be used once per number.
The number cannot start with zero.
Only even numbers are valid, so the last digit must be even.
The output should be the count of distinct three-digit even numbers.
